references: While previous weight clustering approaches effectively compress the exchanged messages, the transmission of both codebooks and compressed weight matrices at each federated round restricts their potential for substantial reduction in data volume. Furthermore, most existing approaches focus on limiting the upstream communication routeÂ (Reisizadeh etÂ al., 2020; Stripelis etÂ al., 2022; Malekijoo etÂ al., 2021; Stich etÂ al., 2018a), and often impose significant computational overhead on the clients. For example, gTop-kÂ (Shi etÂ al., 2019) requires sorting of the weight matrices, while MUCSCÂ (Cui etÂ al., 2021) and FedZipÂ (Malekijoo etÂ al., 2021) applies clustering in each layer of the model. In response to the aforementioned concerns, Â FedCodeÂ primarily transfers codebooks during the FL training process, achieving significant reduction in utilized bandwidth and volume of exchanged messages in the bidirectional communication route, while imposing minimal computational overhead for clients. Specifically,Â FedCodeÂ involves a single K-means clustering algorithm execution for clientsâ€™ weight matrices and a computationally inexpensive binary search for weight reconstruction from the received codebook. TableÂ 1 presents a concise comparison betweenÂ FedCodeÂ and other state-of-the-art communication-efficient FL schemes.

Global Model Performance. Maintaining the performance of the global model is crucial in FL when aiming at reducing communication costs. To achieve a proper balance between data transmission reduction and model accuracy, we carefully controlled three hyperparameters and conducted numerous experiments on diverse classification tasks and different architectures to assess their performance. This demonstrates that with proper fine-tuning of these hyperparameters, FedCodeachieves both high model performance and significant data transmission reduction. These findings highlight that transferring codebook is effective in reducing data transmission while accommodating diverse data distribution. Lastly, comparison with existing approaches, showcases thatÂ FedCodeÂ can train models with competitive performance, while providing a superior reduction in data transmission.

Models and Dataset.
For performance evaluation, we use publicly available datasets of a wide range of classification tasks from both vision and audio domains. To ensure comparability, we use standard training/test splits, as provided by the original datasets, for all datasets. From the vision domain, we use the CIFAR-10Â (Krizhevsky etÂ al., 2009) and CIFAR-100Â (Krizhevsky etÂ al., 2009), where the tasks of interests are object detection among 10 and 100 classes, respectively. As backbone model architectures for those tasks, we use two backbone architectures, namely ResNet-20Â (He etÂ al., 2016), MobileNet (v2)Â (Sandler etÂ al., 2018), covering two of the most widely explored deep learning model architectures in on-device learning thanks to their relatively compact model size. From the audio domain, we use SpeechCommands (v2) datasetÂ (Warden, 2018), where the learning objective is to detect when a particular keyword is spoken out of a set of twelve target classes, and utilize YAMNetÂ (Plakal and Ellis, 2020) (an adaptation of MobileNet for audio modality), which is suitable for edge devicesÂ (Malmberg, 2021). Lastly, in all our experiments, we utilize Adam optimizer with a learning rate of 0.0010.0010.001.

To assess the effectiveness ofÂ FedCodeÂ in reducing the communication cost of FL, we first performed experiments under IID data distribution across all considered datasets and model architectures. The results are presented in Tables 3(a) and 3(b), from which one may notice thatÂ FedCodeÂ effectively reduces communication costs while maintaining a high global model accuracy. Specifically, using ResNet-20 on CIFAR-10,Â FedCodeÂ achieved an average DTR of 14.2 and 15 with ÏğœŒ\rho=111 and ÏğœŒ\rho=0.10.10.1, while maintaining a highly accurate model with accuracy reductions (Î´ğ›¿\delta-Acc) of âˆ’1.43%percent1.43-1.43\% and âˆ’1.51%percent1.51-1.51\%, respectively. In our experiments with MobileNet, which is a larger model compared to ResNet-20,Â FedCodeÂ achieved a DTR of 10.310.310.3 and 10.910.910.9 when ÏğœŒ\rho=111 and ÏğœŒ\rho=0.10.10.1, respectively, while also maintaining high accuracy with Î´ğ›¿\delta-Acc of âˆ’0.04%percent0.04-0.04\% and âˆ’0.33%percent0.33-0.33\%, respectively. From this, we conclude thatÂ FedCodeÂ can effectively reduce the amount of transmitted data during FL training while maintaining a similar/comparable performance to the standard FL process, which holds true across different types of classification tasks.

Furthermore, considering that the transmission rates of compressed weights have a substantial influence on the accuracy and DTR, as depicted in TableÂ 5, we investigated accuracy, DTR, and the amount of transferred bits across various settings within the F1 and F2 range, which varied from 0 to 1. The results demonstrated that decreasing the frequency of compressed weight transfers led to a substantial rise in DTR. However, this decrease also resulted in a reduction of the global modelâ€™s accuracy.

TableÂ 6 presents global model performance for each of the considered baselines, namely FedAvg, FedAvg with weight clustering (referred as FedAvgws) and FedZipÂ (Malekijoo etÂ al., 2021) for the CIFAR-100 dataset. One may notice that by transferring compressed weights via FedAvgws, we can achieve a significant DTR of 5.35.35.3 in both upstream and downstream communication routes, while accuracy drops from 61.22% (reported in FedAvg using the same dataset) to 58.78% . Additionally, FedZip, which introduces Top-k pruning and layer-wise weight clustering to compress individual layers, achieves an accuracy of 57.98% with an upstream DTR of 19.819.819.8. However, as FedZip only performs compression in the upstream communication route the overall DTR falls to 1.91.91.9 since the complete weight matrices need to be downloaded by clients at each federated round. On the other hand,Â FedCodeÂ achieves an accuracy of 58.07%percent58.0758.07\% and demonstrated a significant DTR for both downstream and upstream communication channels. Specifically, we report a downstream DTR of 24.224.224.2 and an upstream DTR of 10.410.410.4, while the overall DTR is 14.614.614.6, surpassing all considered baselines. In addition, Figure 3 illustrates a comparison of the volume of transmitted bits betweenÂ FedCodeÂ , FedAvg, and FedZip, highlighting that the data transferred inÂ FedCodeÂ is notably lower than in the other baseline methods. Therefore,Â FedCodeÂ can be considered as a communication-efficient FL, achieving a competitive accuracy to FedAvg, while significantly reducing the amount of transmitted data and the utilized bandwidth during training.

Data Transmission Reduction. Our experimental results demonstrate thatÂ FedCodeÂ achieved an average 17.8-fold reduction in transmitted data from clients to the server and an average 11.2-fold reduction in transmitted data from the server to clients. Overall, there is an average 12.2-fold reduction in data transmission across the CIFAR-10, CIFAR-100, and SpeechCommands datasets using ResNet-20, MobileNet, and YAMNet architectures, as shown in Tables 3 and 4, while maintaining minimal accuracy loss. Our study reveals that it is unnecessary to transfer complete weight matrices after each federated round. For example, in the case of ResNet-20 on CIFAR100, we set the frequency of transferring compressed weights to clients to 0.25, indicating that only the codebook is transferred to clients in approximately 75% of the federated rounds. Similarly, the frequency of transferring compressed weights to the server was set to 0.5, meaning that for 50% of the federated rounds, only the codebook is transferred from clients to the server. Additionally, when comparing Â FedCodeÂ with other weight clustering techniques, it is evident that transferring the codebook results in a superior reduction in data transmission compared to using weight clustering alone, and it also outperforms FedZip, which employs layer-wise weight clustering, as illustrated in Table 6. These findings highlight the potential of theÂ FedCodeÂ for significantly reducing communication costs in FL.

For example, gTop-kÂ (Shi etÂ al., 2019) requires sorting of the weight matrices, while MUCSCÂ (Cui etÂ al., 2021) and FedZipÂ (Malekijoo etÂ al., 2021) applies clustering in each layer of the model. In response to the aforementioned concerns, Â FedCodeÂ primarily transfers codebooks during the FL training process, achieving significant reduction in utilized bandwidth and volume of exchanged messages in the bidirectional communication route, while imposing minimal computational overhead for clients. Specifically,Â FedCodeÂ involves a single K-means clustering algorithm execution for clientsâ€™ weight matrices and a computationally inexpensive binary search for weight reconstruction from the received codebook. TableÂ 1 presents a concise comparison betweenÂ FedCodeÂ and other state-of-the-art communication-efficient FL schemes.

Models and Dataset.
For performance evaluation, we use publicly available datasets of a wide range of classification tasks from both vision and audio domains. To ensure comparability, we use standard training/test splits, as provided by the original datasets, for all datasets. From the vision domain, we use the CIFAR-10Â (Krizhevsky etÂ al., 2009) and CIFAR-100Â (Krizhevsky etÂ al., 2009), where the tasks of interests are object detection among 10 and 100 classes, respectively. As backbone model architectures for those tasks, we use two backbone architectures, namely ResNet-20Â (He etÂ al., 2016), MobileNet (v2)Â (Sandler etÂ al., 2018), covering two of the most widely explored deep learning model architectures in on-device learning thanks to their relatively compact model size. From the audio domain, we use SpeechCommands (v2) datasetÂ (Warden, 2018), where the learning objective is to detect when a particular keyword is spoken out of a set of twelve target classes, and utilize YAMNetÂ (Plakal and Ellis, 2020) (an adaptation of MobileNet for audio modality), which is suitable for edge devicesÂ (Malmberg, 2021). Lastly, in all our experiments, we utilize Adam optimizer with a learning rate of 0.0010.0010.001.

. InÂ FedCode, we introduce four hyperparameters to control the trade-off between accuracy and data transmission reduction:

. The â€œwordlengthâ€ for measuring the data transmission reduction is set to 32, since PyTorchâ€™s floating-point values have a word length of 32. To ensure the stability of the training procedure in FL (e.g., clusters are not selected based on random weights), we initiate the transferring of codebooks after the second and fourth federated rounds for the ResNet-20 and the MobileNet models, respectively (Rcâ€‹bsubscriptğ‘…ğ‘ğ‘R_{cb}=222/444). An overview of our evaluation setup parameters is shown in TableÂ 2.

Specifically, for IID settings we use a Dirichlet distribution with concentration parameter Î²ğ›½\beta=10.010.010.0 (noted as Dâ€‹iâ€‹râ€‹(10.0)ğ·ğ‘–ğ‘Ÿ10.0Dir(10.0)) over classes, resulting in Cpâ‰ˆ1subscriptğ¶ğ‘1C_{p}\approx 1, while in non-IID setting we use a Î²ğ›½\beta concentration of 0.10.10.1 that produces a Cpâ‰ˆ0.1subscriptğ¶ğ‘0.1C_{p}\approx 0.1 (meaning that 10% of total classes were available per client). In our work, the term non-IID describes a data distribution with both a label distribution skew and a quantity skew. These types of data distributions are common across clientsâ€™ data in federated settingsÂ (Kairouz etÂ al., 2021), where each client frequently corresponds to a particular user (affecting the label distribution), and the application usage across clients can differ substantially (affecting the amount of data among clients). For a fair comparison between our experiments, we managed any randomness during data partitioning and training procedures with a seed value.

To assess the effectiveness ofÂ FedCodeÂ in reducing the communication cost of FL, we first performed experiments under IID data distribution across all considered datasets and model architectures. We measured the DTR and model accuracy compared to standard FL. The results are presented in Tables 3(a) and 3(b), from which one may notice thatÂ FedCodeÂ effectively reduces communication costs while maintaining a high global model accuracy. In our experiments with MobileNet, which is a larger model compared to ResNet-20,Â FedCodeÂ achieved a DTR of 10.310.310.3 and 10.910.910.9 when ÏğœŒ\rho=111 and ÏğœŒ\rho=0.10.10.1, respectively, while also maintaining high accuracy with Î´ğ›¿\delta-Acc of âˆ’0.04%percent0.04-0.04\% and âˆ’0.33%percent0.33-0.33\%, respectively. Similarly, when applyingÂ FedCodeÂ to MobileNet on CIFAR-100, we obtained a DTR of 10.610.610.6 and 10.910.910.9 for ÏğœŒ\rho=00 and ÏğœŒ\rho=0.10.10.1, respectively, while keeping the modelâ€™s performance on par with the standard FL models (i.e., achieving Î´ğ›¿\delta-Acc of âˆ’1.67%percent1.67-1.67\% and âˆ’1.93%percent1.93-1.93\%).

In addition, we assessed theÂ FedCodeÂ â€™s performance under audio classification tasks using YAMNetÂ (Plakal and Ellis, 2020) architecture on SpeechCommandsÂ (Warden, 2018) dataset, as detailed in Table 4. To assess the impact of different data distributions onÂ FedCodeÂ performance, we conducted experiments using ResNet-20 and MobileNet on CIFAR-10 and CIFAR-100 under non-IID data distribution. Our experiments with MobileNet showed thatFedCodeÂ achieved high accuracy with accuracy losses of âˆ’0.28%percent0.28-0.28\% and âˆ’0.81%percent0.81-0.81\% for ÏğœŒ\rho values of 111 and 0.10.10.1, respectively. Furthermore, whenFedCodeÂ was applied to MobileNet on CIFAR-100, the modelâ€™s performance resulted in an accuracy loss of âˆ’2.67%percent2.67-2.67\% and âˆ’2.91%percent2.91-2.91\% for ÏğœŒ\rho values of 00 and 0.10.10.1, respectively. As shown in Table 3, the corresponding data transmission reduction indicates the effectiveness of the proposed approach in reducing data transmission while handling different data distributions, where it can achieve competitive accuracy.

Furthermore, considering that the transmission rates of compressed weights have a substantial influence on the accuracy and DTR, as depicted in TableÂ 5, we investigated accuracy, DTR, and the amount of transferred bits across various settings within the F1 and F2 range, which varied from 0 to 1. The results demonstrated that decreasing the frequency of compressed weight transfers led to a substantial rise in DTR. However, this decrease also resulted in a reduction of the global modelâ€™s accuracy.

TableÂ 6 presents global model performance for each of the considered baselines, namely FedAvg, FedAvg with weight clustering (referred as FedAvgws) and FedZipÂ (Malekijoo etÂ al., 2021) for the CIFAR-100 dataset. One may notice that by transferring compressed weights via FedAvgws, we can achieve a significant DTR of 5.35.35.3 in both upstream and downstream communication routes, while accuracy drops from 61.22% (reported in FedAvg using the same dataset) to 58.78% . Additionally, FedZip, which introduces Top-k pruning and layer-wise weight clustering to compress individual layers, achieves an accuracy of 57.98% with an upstream DTR of 19.819.819.8. However, as FedZip only performs compression in the upstream communication route the overall DTR falls to 1.91.91.9 since the complete weight matrices need to be downloaded by clients at each federated round. On the other hand,Â FedCodeÂ achieves an accuracy of 58.07%percent58.0758.07\% and demonstrated a significant DTR for both downstream and upstream communication channels. Specifically, we report a downstream DTR of 24.224.224.2 and an upstream DTR of 10.410.410.4, while the overall DTR is 14.614.614.6, surpassing all considered baselines. In addition, Figure 3 illustrates a comparison of the volume of transmitted bits betweenÂ FedCodeÂ , FedAvg, and FedZip, highlighting that the data transferred inÂ FedCodeÂ is notably lower than in the other baseline methods. Therefore,Â FedCodeÂ can be considered as a communication-efficient FL, achieving a competitive accuracy to FedAvg, while significantly reducing the amount of transmitted data and the utilized bandwidth during training.

Global Model Performance. Maintaining the performance of the global model is crucial in FL when aiming at reducing communication costs. To achieve a proper balance between data transmission reduction and model accuracy, we carefully controlled three hyperparameters and conducted numerous experiments on diverse classification tasks and different architectures to assess their performance. Tables 3 and 4 present the results of our experiments, indicating that when every client actively participates in each round theÂ FedCodeÂ approach resulted in an accuracy loss of less than 2%percent22\% for most cases, with the exception of ResNet-20 on CIFAR-100. However, FigureÂ 6 illustrates that by adjusting the hyperparameters, we were able to further reduce the accuracy loss. For instance, by fine-tuning our hyperparameters to the frequency of transferring compressed weights for downstream and upstream communication routes to 0.330.330.33 and 0.50.50.5 together with 128128128 cluster centers, the accuracy loss for ResNet-20 on CIFAR-100 decreased to 2.03%percent2.032.03\%. This demonstrates that with proper fine-tuning of these hyperparameters, FedCodeachieves both high model performance and significant data transmission reduction. Furthermore,Â FedCodeÂ could retain its performance even under non-IID data distribution scenarios, with Resnet-20 reporting an accuracy loss of 1.431.431.43 and 3.153.153.15 and MobileNet reporting an accuracy loss of 0.280.280.28 and 2.672.672.67 on CIFAR10 and CIFAR100, respectively. The results presented in Table 3 also revealed that when the clientsâ€™ participation rate was adjusted to 10 percent, FedCode still achieved a comparable level of accuracy with an average accuracy reduction of 2.27 for Resnet and 1.13 for MobileNet on IID data distribution, and 2.7 for Resnet and 1.86 for MobileNet on non-IID data distribution. These findings highlight that transferring codebook is effective in reducing data transmission while accommodating diverse data distribution. Lastly, comparison with existing approaches, showcases thatÂ FedCodeÂ can train models with competitive performance, while providing a superior reduction in data transmission.

Data Transmission Reduction. Our experimental results demonstrate thatÂ FedCodeÂ achieved an average 17.8-fold reduction in transmitted data from clients to the server and an average 11.2-fold reduction in transmitted data from the server to clients. Overall, there is an average 12.2-fold reduction in data transmission across the CIFAR-10, CIFAR-100, and SpeechCommands datasets using ResNet-20, MobileNet, and YAMNet architectures, as shown in Tables 3 and 4, while maintaining minimal accuracy loss. Our study reveals that it is unnecessary to transfer complete weight matrices after each federated round. For example, in the case of ResNet-20 on CIFAR100, we set the frequency of transferring compressed weights to clients to 0.25, indicating that only the codebook is transferred to clients in approximately 75% of the federated rounds. Similarly, the frequency of transferring compressed weights to the server was set to 0.5, meaning that for 50% of the federated rounds, only the codebook is transferred from clients to the server. Additionally, when comparing Â FedCodeÂ with other weight clustering techniques, it is evident that transferring the codebook results in a superior reduction in data transmission compared to using weight clustering alone, and it also outperforms FedZip, which employs layer-wise weight clustering, as illustrated in Table 6. These findings highlight the potential of theÂ FedCodeÂ for significantly reducing communication costs in FL.

To achieve a proper balance between data transmission reduction and model accuracy, we carefully controlled three hyperparameters and conducted numerous experiments on diverse classification tasks and different architectures to assess their performance. However, FigureÂ 6 illustrates that by adjusting the hyperparameters, we were able to further reduce the accuracy loss. For instance, by fine-tuning our hyperparameters to the frequency of transferring compressed weights for downstream and upstream communication routes to 0.330.330.33 and 0.50.50.5 together with 128128128 cluster centers, the accuracy loss for ResNet-20 on CIFAR-100 decreased to 2.03%percent2.032.03\%. This demonstrates that with proper fine-tuning of these hyperparameters, FedCodeachieves both high model performance and significant data transmission reduction. The results presented in Table 3 also revealed that when the clientsâ€™ participation rate was adjusted to 10 percent, FedCode still achieved a comparable level of accuracy with an average accuracy reduction of 2.27 for Resnet and 1.13 for MobileNet on IID data distribution, and 2.7 for Resnet and 1.86 for MobileNet on non-IID data distribution. These findings highlight that transferring codebook is effective in reducing data transmission while accommodating diverse data distribution. Lastly, comparison with existing approaches, showcases thatÂ FedCodeÂ can train models with competitive performance, while providing a superior reduction in data transmission.

Our experimental results demonstrate thatÂ FedCodeÂ achieved an average 17.8-fold reduction in transmitted data from clients to the server and an average 11.2-fold reduction in transmitted data from the server to clients. Overall, there is an average 12.2-fold reduction in data transmission across the CIFAR-10, CIFAR-100, and SpeechCommands datasets using ResNet-20, MobileNet, and YAMNet architectures, as shown in Tables 3 and 4, while maintaining minimal accuracy loss. Our study reveals that it is unnecessary to transfer complete weight matrices after each federated round. For example, in the case of ResNet-20 on CIFAR100, we set the frequency of transferring compressed weights to clients to 0.25, indicating that only the codebook is transferred to clients in approximately 75% of the federated rounds. Similarly, the frequency of transferring compressed weights to the server was set to 0.5, meaning that for 50% of the federated rounds, only the codebook is transferred from clients to the server. Additionally, when comparing Â FedCodeÂ with other weight clustering techniques, it is evident that transferring the codebook results in a superior reduction in data transmission compared to using weight clustering alone, and it also outperforms FedZip, which employs layer-wise weight clustering, as illustrated in Table 6. These findings highlight the potential of theÂ FedCodeÂ for significantly reducing communication costs in FL.

references: While previous weight clustering approaches effectively compress the exchanged messages, the transmission of both codebooks and compressed weight matrices at each federated round restricts their potential for substantial reduction in data volume. Furthermore, most existing approaches focus on limiting the upstream communication routeÂ (Reisizadeh etÂ al., 2020; Stripelis etÂ al., 2022; Malekijoo etÂ al., 2021; Stich etÂ al., 2018a), and often impose significant computational overhead on the clients. For example, gTop-kÂ (Shi etÂ al., 2019) requires sorting of the weight matrices, while MUCSCÂ (Cui etÂ al., 2021) and FedZipÂ (Malekijoo etÂ al., 2021) applies clustering in each layer of the model. In response to the aforementioned concerns, Â FedCodeÂ primarily transfers codebooks during the FL training process, achieving significant reduction in utilized bandwidth and volume of exchanged messages in the bidirectional communication route, while imposing minimal computational overhead for clients. Specifically,Â FedCodeÂ involves a single K-means clustering algorithm execution for clientsâ€™ weight matrices and a computationally inexpensive binary search for weight reconstruction from the received codebook. references: While previous weight clustering approaches effectively compress the exchanged messages, the transmission of both codebooks and compressed weight matrices at each federated round restricts their potential for substantial reduction in data volume. Furthermore, most existing approaches focus on limiting the upstream communication routeÂ (Reisizadeh etÂ al., 2020; Stripelis etÂ al., 2022; Malekijoo etÂ al., 2021; Stich etÂ al., 2018a), and often impose significant computational overhead on the clients. For example, gTop-kÂ (Shi etÂ al., 2019) requires sorting of the weight matrices, while MUCSCÂ (Cui etÂ al., 2021) and FedZipÂ (Malekijoo etÂ al., 2021) applies clustering in each layer of the model. In response to the aforementioned concerns, Â FedCodeÂ primarily transfers codebooks during the FL training process, achieving significant reduction in utilized bandwidth and volume of exchanged messages in the bidirectional communication route, while imposing minimal computational overhead for clients. Specifically,Â FedCodeÂ involves a single K-means clustering algorithm execution for clientsâ€™ weight matrices and a computationally inexpensive binary search for weight reconstruction from the received codebook. TableÂ 1 presents a concise comparison betweenÂ FedCodeÂ and other state-of-the-art communication-efficient FL schemes.

Models and Dataset.
For performance evaluation, we use publicly available datasets of a wide range of classification tasks from both vision and audio domains. To ensure comparability, we use standard training/test splits, as provided by the original datasets, for all datasets. From the vision domain, we use the CIFAR-10Â (Krizhevsky etÂ al., 2009) and CIFAR-100Â (Krizhevsky etÂ al., 2009), where the tasks of interests are object detection among 10 and 100 classes, respectively. As backbone model architectures for those tasks, we use two backbone architectures, namely ResNet-20Â (He etÂ al., 2016), MobileNet (v2)Â (Sandler etÂ al., 2018), covering two of the most widely explored deep learning model architectures in on-device learning thanks to their relatively compact model size. From the audio domain, we use SpeechCommands (v2) datasetÂ (Warden, 2018), where the learning objective is to detect when a particular keyword is spoken out of a set of twelve target classes, and utilize YAMNetÂ (Plakal and Ellis, 2020) (an adaptation of MobileNet for audio modality), which is suitable for edge devicesÂ (Malmberg, 2021). Lastly, in all our experiments, we utilize Adam optimizer with a learning rate of 0.0010.0010.001.

1) number of clients - Nğ‘N, 
2) client train epochs per round - Eğ¸E, and 
3) number of rounds - Rğ‘…R, 
4) clientsâ€™ participation rate per round - ÏğœŒ\rho, 
5) client class concentration - Cpsubscriptğ¶ğ‘C_{p}
. InÂ FedCode, we introduce four hyperparameters to control the trade-off between accuracy and data transmission reduction: 

1) number of clusters - Kğ¾K, and 
2) minimum round for codebook transfer - Rcâ€‹bsubscriptğ‘…ğ‘ğ‘R_{cb} - 
3) compressed weights upstream transfer rate - F1subscriptğ¹1F_{1},

. The â€œwordlengthâ€ for measuring the data transmission reduction is set to 32, since PyTorchâ€™s floating-point values have a word length of 32. To ensure the stability of the training procedure in FL (e.g., clusters are not selected based on random weights), we initiate the transferring of codebooks after the second and fourth federated rounds for the ResNet-20 and the MobileNet models, respectively (Rcâ€‹bsubscriptğ‘…ğ‘ğ‘R_{cb}=222/444). An overview of our evaluation setup parameters is shown in TableÂ 2.
For the data distribution process in our federated experiments, we explored both IID (Cpâ‰ˆ1subscriptğ¶ğ‘1C_{p}\approx 1) and non-IID (Cp<<1much-less-thansubscriptğ¶ğ‘1C_{p}<<1) distributions, where we partitioned our datasets across the available clients in a non-overlapping fashion, controlling both the amount of data across clients and the classes availability across clients. Specifically, for IID settings we use a Dirichlet distribution with concentration parameter Î²ğ›½\beta=10.010.010.0 (noted as Dâ€‹iâ€‹râ€‹(10.0)ğ·ğ‘–ğ‘Ÿ10.0Dir(10.0)) over classes, resulting in Cpâ‰ˆ1subscriptğ¶ğ‘1C_{p}\approx 1, while in non-IID setting we use a Î²ğ›½\beta concentration of 0.10.10.1 that produces a Cpâ‰ˆ0.1subscriptğ¶ğ‘0.1C_{p}\approx 0.1 (meaning that 10% of total classes were available per client). It is worth mentioning that even if the meaning of non-IID is generally straightforward, data can be non-IID in many ways. For a concise review of the various non-IID distribution schemes in FL, we refer an interested reader toÂ (Kairouz etÂ al., 2021). In our work, the term non-IID describes a data distribution with both a label distribution skew and a quantity skew. These types of data distributions are common across clientsâ€™ data in federated settingsÂ (Kairouz etÂ al., 2021), where each client frequently corresponds to a particular user (affecting the label distribution), and the application usage across clients can differ substantially (affecting the amount of data among clients). For a fair comparison between our experiments, we managed any randomness during data partitioning and training procedures with a seed value.

To assess the effectiveness ofÂ FedCodeÂ in reducing the communication cost of FL, we first performed experiments under IID data distribution across all considered datasets and model architectures. We measured the DTR and model accuracy compared to standard FL. Using ResNet-20 on CIFAR100, the results were similarly impressive, with FedCodeÂ achieving an average DTR of 14.6 and 15.1 for ÏğœŒ\rho=111 and ÏğœŒ\rho=0.10.10.1, while maintaining a comparable level of accuracy, as indicated by a Î´ğ›¿\delta-Acc of âˆ’3.19%percent3.19-3.19\% and âˆ’3.04%percent3.04-3.04\%, respectively. In our experiments with MobileNet, which is a larger model compared to ResNet-20,Â FedCodeÂ achieved a DTR of 10.310.310.3 and 10.910.910.9 when ÏğœŒ\rho=111 and ÏğœŒ\rho=0.10.10.1, respectively, while also maintaining high accuracy with Î´ğ›¿\delta-Acc of âˆ’0.04%percent0.04-0.04\% and âˆ’0.33%percent0.33-0.33\%, respectively. Similarly, when applyingÂ FedCodeÂ to MobileNet on CIFAR-100, we obtained a DTR of 10.610.610.6 and 10.910.910.9 for ÏğœŒ\rho=00 and ÏğœŒ\rho=0.10.10.1, respectively, while keeping the modelâ€™s performance on par with the standard FL models (i.e., achieving Î´ğ›¿\delta-Acc of âˆ’1.67%percent1.67-1.67\% and âˆ’1.93%percent1.93-1.93\%).

In addition, we assessed theÂ FedCodeÂ â€™s performance under audio classification tasks using YAMNetÂ (Plakal and Ellis, 2020) architecture on SpeechCommandsÂ (Warden, 2018) dataset, as detailed in Table 4. It is worth noting that a similar pattern like MobileNet and ResNet-20, emerged, whereÂ FedCodeÂ achieved a DTR of 101010 with minimal impact on the accuracy of the models. From this, we conclude thatÂ FedCodeÂ can effectively reduce the amount of transmitted data during FL training while maintaining a similar/comparable performance to the standard FL process, which holds true across different types of classification tasks.

To assess the impact of different data distributions onÂ FedCodeÂ performance, we conducted experiments using ResNet-20 and MobileNet on CIFAR-10 and CIFAR-100 under non-IID data distribution. When we applied ResNet-20 to CIFAR-10, theÂ FedCodeÂ demonstrated remarkable accuracy, resulting in an accuracy reduction of âˆ’1.07%percent1.07-1.07\% and âˆ’1.67%percent1.67-1.67\% for ÏğœŒ\rho values of 111 and 0.10.10.1, respectively. Similarly, for ResNet-20 on CIFAR-100,FedCodeÂ achieved a comparable level of accuracy with accuracy reductions of âˆ’3.19%percent3.19-3.19\% and âˆ’3.74%percent3.74-3.74\% for ÏğœŒ\rho values of 111 and 0.10.10.1. Our experiments with MobileNet showed thatFedCodeÂ achieved high accuracy with accuracy losses of âˆ’0.28%percent0.28-0.28\% and âˆ’0.81%percent0.81-0.81\% for ÏğœŒ\rho values of 111 and 0.10.10.1, respectively. Furthermore, whenFedCodeÂ was applied to MobileNet on CIFAR-100, the modelâ€™s performance resulted in an accuracy loss of âˆ’2.67%percent2.67-2.67\% and âˆ’2.91%percent2.91-2.91\% for ÏğœŒ\rho values of 00 and 0.10.10.1, respectively. As shown in Table 3, the corresponding data transmission reduction indicates the effectiveness of the proposed approach in reducing data transmission while handling different data distributions, where it can achieve competitive accuracy.

Furthermore, considering that the transmission rates of compressed weights have a substantial influence on the accuracy and DTR, as depicted in TableÂ 5, we investigated accuracy, DTR, and the amount of transferred bits across various settings within the F1 and F2 range, which varied from 0 to 1. The results demonstrated that decreasing the frequency of compressed weight transfers led to a substantial rise in DTR. However, this decrease also resulted in a reduction of the global modelâ€™s accuracy.

TableÂ 6 presents global model performance for each of the considered baselines, namely FedAvg, FedAvg with weight clustering (referred as FedAvgws) and FedZipÂ (Malekijoo etÂ al., 2021) for the CIFAR-100 dataset. One may notice that by transferring compressed weights via FedAvgws, we can achieve a significant DTR of 5.35.35.3 in both upstream and downstream communication routes, while accuracy drops from 61.22% (reported in FedAvg using the same dataset) to 58.78% . Additionally, FedZip, which introduces Top-k pruning and layer-wise weight clustering to compress individual layers, achieves an accuracy of 57.98% with an upstream DTR of 19.819.819.8. However, as FedZip only performs compression in the upstream communication route the overall DTR falls to 1.91.91.9 since the complete weight matrices need to be downloaded by clients at each federated round. On the other hand,Â FedCodeÂ achieves an accuracy of 58.07%percent58.0758.07\% and demonstrated a significant DTR for both downstream and upstream communication channels. Specifically, we report a downstream DTR of 24.224.224.2 and an upstream DTR of 10.410.410.4, while the overall DTR is 14.614.614.6, surpassing all considered baselines. In addition, Figure 3 illustrates a comparison of the volume of transmitted bits betweenÂ FedCodeÂ , FedAvg, and FedZip, highlighting that the data transferred inÂ FedCodeÂ is notably lower than in the other baseline methods. Therefore,Â FedCodeÂ can be considered as a communication-efficient FL, achieving a competitive accuracy to FedAvg, while significantly reducing the amount of transmitted data and the utilized bandwidth during training.

Global Model Performance. Maintaining the performance of the global model is crucial in FL when aiming at reducing communication costs. To achieve a proper balance between data transmission reduction and model accuracy, we carefully controlled three hyperparameters and conducted numerous experiments on diverse classification tasks and different architectures to assess their performance. Tables 3 and 4 present the results of our experiments, indicating that when every client actively participates in each round theÂ FedCodeÂ approach resulted in an accuracy loss of less than 2%percent22\% for most cases, with the exception of ResNet-20 on CIFAR-100. However, FigureÂ 6 illustrates that by adjusting the hyperparameters, we were able to further reduce the accuracy loss. For instance, by fine-tuning our hyperparameters to the frequency of transferring compressed weights for downstream and upstream communication routes to 0.330.330.33 and 0.50.50.5 together with 128128128 cluster centers, the accuracy loss for ResNet-20 on CIFAR-100 decreased to 2.03%percent2.032.03\%. This demonstrates that with proper fine-tuning of these hyperparameters, FedCodeachieves both high model performance and significant data transmission reduction. Furthermore,Â FedCodeÂ could retain its performance even under non-IID data distribution scenarios, with Resnet-20 reporting an accuracy loss of 1.431.431.43 and 3.153.153.15 and MobileNet reporting an accuracy loss of 0.280.280.28 and 2.672.672.67 on CIFAR10 and CIFAR100, respectively. The results presented in Table 3 also revealed that when the clientsâ€™ participation rate was adjusted to 10 percent, FedCode still achieved a comparable level of accuracy with an average accuracy reduction of 2.27 for Resnet and 1.13 for MobileNet on IID data distribution, and 2.7 for Resnet and 1.86 for MobileNet on non-IID data distribution. These findings highlight that transferring codebook is effective in reducing data transmission while accommodating diverse data distribution. Lastly, comparison with existing approaches, showcases thatÂ FedCodeÂ can train models with competitive performance, while providing a superior reduction in data transmission.

Data Transmission Reduction. Our experimental results demonstrate thatÂ FedCodeÂ achieved an average 17.8-fold reduction in transmitted data from clients to the server and an average 11.2-fold reduction in transmitted data from the server to clients. Overall, there is an average 12.2-fold reduction in data transmission across the CIFAR-10, CIFAR-100, and SpeechCommands datasets using ResNet-20, MobileNet, and YAMNet architectures, as shown in Tables 3 and 4, while maintaining minimal accuracy loss. Our study reveals that it is unnecessary to transfer complete weight matrices after each federated round. For example, in the case of ResNet-20 on CIFAR100, we set the frequency of transferring compressed weights to clients to 0.25, indicating that only the codebook is transferred to clients in approximately 75% of the federated rounds. Similarly, the frequency of transferring compressed weights to the server was set to 0.5, meaning that for 50% of the federated rounds, only the codebook is transferred from clients to the server. Additionally, when comparing Â FedCodeÂ with other weight clustering techniques, it is evident that transferring the codebook results in a superior reduction in data transmission compared to using weight clustering alone, and it also outperforms FedZip, which employs layer-wise weight clustering, as illustrated in Table 6. These findings highlight the potential of theÂ FedCodeÂ for significantly reducing communication costs in FL.

Data Transmission Reduction. Our experimental results demonstrate thatÂ FedCodeÂ achieved an average 17.8-fold reduction in transmitted data from clients to the server and an average 11.2-fold reduction in transmitted data from the server to clients. Overall, there is an average 12.2-fold reduction in data transmission across the CIFAR-10, CIFAR-100, and SpeechCommands datasets using ResNet-20, MobileNet, and YAMNet architectures, as shown in Tables 3 and 4, while maintaining minimal accuracy loss. Our study reveals that it is unnecessary to transfer complete weight matrices after each federated round. For example, in the case of ResNet-20 on CIFAR100, we set the frequency of transferring compressed weights to clients to 0.25, indicating that only the codebook is transferred to clients in approximately 75% of the federated rounds. Similarly, the frequency of transferring compressed weights to the server was set to 0.5, meaning that for 50% of the federated rounds, only the codebook is transferred from clients to the server. Additionally, when comparing Â FedCodeÂ with other weight clustering techniques, it is evident that transferring the codebook results in a superior reduction in data transmission compared to using weight clustering alone, and it also outperforms FedZip, which employs layer-wise weight clustering, as illustrated in Table 6. These findings highlight the potential of theÂ FedCodeÂ for significantly reducing communication costs in FL.
